docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: Welcome to my technical writing portfolio. This portfolio has two independent parts: a single-page case study and a small example docs set for a fictional license manager app. The case study tells a delivery story. The example docs show my information architecture and writing.

docs.title: What’s inside
docs.text:
• Case study

    A concise narrative of the starting problem, tooling decisions, architecture, and outcomes. It focuses on why I made each choice and what it enabled.

  • Example docs set

    Note

    The example docs exist only to illustrate IA and voice; they’re independent of the case study.

    Diátaxis-based docs for a fictional licensing platform. I produced a complete Markdown set organized into Tutorials, How-to, Reference, Explanation, and Troubleshooting, with a Getting started portal to help a new user find their way to the information they need for a quick first success. Built with MkDocs Material, with reusable templates and style rules. Result: fast findability, clean navigation, and a structure that would scale.

docs.title: How to read
docs.text:
1. Start with the case study to understand my approach to diagnosing problems and shipping a docs program.
  2. Browse the example docs to see structure, page types, and copy you could drop into a real product.

docs.title: Confidentiality
docs.text: I have replaced any internal identifiers, proprietary assets, and confidential references with [neutral placeholders]. I intend this portfolio solely to show documentation strategy and systems, not internal technologies or business practices. Each document has undergone a thorough review and sanitizing process to ensure full compliance with all nondisclosure agreements and confidentiality obligations.

docs.title: Executive summary
docs.text:
Confidentiality

This is a sanitized case study of a documentation system I built from scratch. No NDAs were harmed in the making of this site.

I designed and maintained a docs‑as‑code platform for [Acme Corp] using MkDocs and Material for MkDocs. The system uses Git workflows, CI validation, and lightweight theme overrides to keep documentation reliable, reviewable, and easy to evolve. The result is a predictable publishing cycle with consistent standards, accessible UI patterns, and fast feedback for contributors.

docs.title: Starting problem
docs.text: I needed to bring existing documentation from several teams and formats into one system while keeping writing standards consistent. I needed tooling that would catch broken links and style drift early, without adding friction for authors. The system and workflows also had to support multi‑project repositories and a growing contributor base of both technical and non-technical authors.

docs.title: Design decisions
docs.text:
I knew I wanted a docs-as-code system and workflows. I chose an MkDocs + Material stack, with Python dependencies pinned in requirements.txt.

For technical accuracy and consistency of voice, I required pull requests for every merge from a working feature/* branch to a dev/* branch. This also mirrored company policy for similar merges in other repositories.

NDAs prevent me from showing real PR examples or CI screenshots here.

A Jenkins pipeline validated structure, links, and style in the dev/* branches, and deployments ran from the main branch. By policy, merges to main were only allowed after a successful dev/* build; we kept governance in the review and CI stages to catch problems early.

Accessibility stayed in scope throughout: readable typography, high contrast, and a few small, targeted JavaScript improvements.

docs.title: Why this approach
docs.text:
• Docs‑as‑code aligns with existing engineering practices and keeps history and review in Git.
  • Material for MkDocs provides an accessible, extensible base with minimal maintenance.
  • Plugin‑driven features cover search, redirects, tabbed content, syntax highlighting, and annotated examples.
  • Lightweight overrides reduce upgrade risk while allowing brand‑level adjustments.

docs.title: Architecture
docs.text:
graph LR
    A[Writers &<br>Engineers] -->|Commit<br>Markdown| B[Git<br>Repository]
    B -->|CI Build/<br>MkDocs| C[Static<br>Site]
    C --> D[Hosting<br>Platform]

Key decisions:

  • Single repository per product with docs/, mkdocs.yml, and optional overrides/.
  • MkDocs build with --strict to fail on structural or internal‑link errors.
  • LinkChecker for external links; Vale for style and terminology.
  • Small template overrides only where needed.

docs.title: Theme and features
docs.text:
mkdocs.yml (sanitized excerpt)
theme:
  name: material
  logo: img/home_icon.png
  favicon: img/favicon.png
  font:
    text: Noto Sans
    code: Courier Prime
  features:
    - navigation.path
    - navigation.tabs
    - navigation.top
    - content.code.annotate
    - content.code.copy
    - content.tabs.link
    - content.tooltips
plugins:
  - search
  - glightbox
  - redirects
markdown_extensions:
  - admonition
  - toc:
      title: On this page...
      permalink: 🔗
      permalink_title: Link to this heading
  - pymdownx.highlight
  - pymdownx.tabbed
  - pymdownx.snippets:
      check_paths: true
extra_css:
  - assets/stylesheets/extra.css
extra_javascript:
  - assets/javascripts/extra.js

docs.title: Authoring patterns
docs.text:
Tabbed content keeps platform variants together.

macOSWindows

Run install.sh.

Run install.bat.

Copy buttons and annotated code support command‑heavy topics.

Install tools
pip install -r requirements.txt  # (1)!

Build the site with strict validation

  1. Fails on broken links or invalid paths

docs.title: Styling and small JS
Workflow and governance
docs.text:
1. Author works in a feature/* branch (1) and previews locally with mkdocs serve.

    1. Short‑lived task branches tied to Jira issues.

  2. Open PR into the appropriate dev/* (1) branch for review.

    1. Active branches for ongoing updates. CI builds generate internal previews.

  3. PR approval creates merge commit in dev/*.

  4. Jenkins pipeline runs on dev/*: install dependencies → mkdocs build --strict → external link check → Vale → artifacts and notifications.

  5. During release prep, assuming the latest CI build in the dev/* branch succeeded, merge the dev/* branch into main (1) and deploy.

    1. Production documentation. Reviewed and validated content only.

  6. Feedback loop: BugHerd lets non‑technical reviewers comment directly on the rendered pages. Each BugHerd card links back to the source page for quick triage, and fixes move through the same PR and CI path.

docs.title: Risks and trade‑offs
docs.text:
MkDocs’ Lunr-based client-side search sacrifices advanced features like exact phrase matching in exchange for a zero-infrastructure solution that’s fast, works entirely in the browser, and can be deployed anywhere static files can be hosted. That ‘anywhere’ includes downloaded or in-app documentation, which modern browsers prevent due to cross-file access restrictions. With input from stakeholders, I chose this trade-off because a significant subset of customers were constrained to airgapped environments, where most client-side search would not have functioned at all.

I kept pre-commit hooks out of scope to keep tooling simpler for reluctant contributors. That shifted enforcement to CI, so errors surface after a push instead of before a commit. To mitigate this, we required PR review for technical accuracy and voice, and ran the CI builds in strict mode with Vale and Linkchecker. This caught broken links, structure issues, and style drift before anything reached main.

Merges to main weren’t restricted, so that anyone on the team could publish if needed. This of course carries its own risks: if anyone can publish, then anyone might publish! We mitigated this by making the deployment itself a manual step, and with policy:

  • Merge to main only as part of release prep, and only after a successful dev/* build.
  • Deploy only from main, using a manual deploy job.

I kept theme overrides minimal. That traded fine-grained brand control for easy tooling upgrades and low maintenance.

docs.title: Outcomes
docs.text: The program now runs on a predictable publishing cadence aligned with product releases. Technical and non-technical authors are willing and able to contribute to the documentation and can see in real time what they are creating. Strict-mode builds and external link checks surface errors early in the cycle. Vale keeps terminology and tone consistent across teams. The UI remains uniform and accessible through tooling updates, with small, maintainable refinements where needed.

docs.title: Get started with Acme licensing
docs.text:
This page is a fast path for new users. It links to the right topics in the documentation to help you install Acme License Engine and Acme License Hub, sign in, and run licensed apps.

Starting paths are below for two roles:

  • End users: People who need to run licensed apps
  • Admins: IT professionals who need to configure a local license server so that end users can run licensed apps using shared licenses

docs.title: Before you begin
docs.text:
You need

  • Administrator rights on the machine
  • Internet access
  • An Acme account
  • Optional for administrators: one product with sharable seats

docs.title: Get started
docs.text:
1. Check system requirements

    Review supported OS versions and network expectations. If your setup is out of scope, fix that first.

  2. Install Acme License Engine and Hub (tutorial)

    When the installer finishes, open Acme License Hub and sign in to confirm access.

  3. First success

    Pick a path based on your role.

    • End users

      1. Use the Hub to activate a license for your app.
      2. Launch a protected app and confirm it starts without a license error.

    • Admins

      1. Set up a basic local server (tutorial).
      2. Connect one client on the same LAN (tutorial).
      3. On the client machine, launch a protected app and confirm it starts without a license error.

  4. Next steps

    • End users

      • How-to → Start or end a Cloud session

    • Admins

      • How-to → Require a server password
      • How-to → Export a client configuration file
      • Explanation → How sharable licenses work

docs.text:
• Troubleshooting → Engine and Hub errors
  • Troubleshooting → Server not discovered

docs.title: Individual use
docs.text: This page explains how Acme licensing works for a single user.

docs.title: What this system is for
docs.text: Acme License Hub allows you to run software protected by Acme. You redeem entitlements to your account and activate them to a location your machine can reach. This allows you to run protected apps, which verify the license via the installed Acme License Engine.

docs.title: Components
docs.text:
Acme License Hub

Desktop app for signing in, redeeming, activating/deactivating, and viewing license state.

Acme License Engine

The runtime installed on your machine that licensed apps use to check entitlements.

Locations

Where an active seat lives:

  • Acme dongle: hardware you control, attached by USB.
  • Acme Cloud: a session you open in Hub; available while signed in.
License → activations A license may allow more than one activation. This allows more than one machine at a time to launch the software.

docs.title: Choosing a location
docs.text:
Primary need Recommended location Why Portable and offline Local Acme dongle Works without internet; easy to move between machines. Always-online and minimal hardware Acme License Cloud No USB key; sign in where you work.

There is no single “best” option; pick based on where you spend most of your time.

docs.title: Boundaries and failure domains
docs.text:
Think in layers when something fails:

  1. Location presence: Is the dongle connected, or is the Cloud session open?
  2. Reachability: Does the Engine see that location (USB recognized, internet up)?
  3. Eligibility: Is the license Cloud-enabled or intended for dongle use?

docs.title: Security and privacy
docs.text: Entitlements remain in a protected location (dongle or Cloud). Apps receive an authorization, not raw secrets. Your sign-in controls access to Cloud; physical custody and account sign-in control access to a dongle.

docs.title: Related reading
docs.text:
• Individual tasks: Redeem an activation code, Activate a license, Deactivate a license
  • Cloud use: Start or end a Cloud session
  • Hardware care: Repair an Acme dongle

docs.title: License server
docs.text: This page explains how Acme’s server feature enables a shared pool of seats for many users.

docs.title: What this adds to the individual model
docs.text:
Shared licensing layers a server on top of individual components. Seats live on an Acme dongle you control, but clients obtain leases over the network.

Key constraint: for shared use, seats must be on an Acme dongle attached to the server host. Clients lease from that server across the LAN/VPN.

docs.title: Components
docs.text:
Server

Mediates clients and seats, enforces access policy, tracks leases and denials.

Server’s Acme dongle

Holds the seats to be shared. Physical control of this device is part of the security model.

Clients

Workstations running protected apps. They connect to the server and request leases.

Lease

Time-bound record that links a specific seat to that client.

Acme License Hub

Used by administrators and users to view state and connect clients to servers.

docs.title: Connection models
docs.text:
How clients find the server is a separate concern from how licenses are enforced.

In pilot scenarios on a single subnet, Public discovery minimizes setup and reduces addressing errors. In production (especially in managed networks, multi-subnet, or VPN environments), Private connections provide tighter change control and predictable onboarding.

Public (discoverable) The server advertises on the local subnet. Clients select it from Discovered. Pros: minimal client setup; reduces input errors on a single subnet. Cons: limited to the local subnet; broader visibility on the LAN.

Private No LAN announcement. Clients import a configuration file or enter the server address/port. Pros: works across subnets/VPNs; predictable onboarding; clearer access boundaries. Cons: requires distribution of the config/address; slightly more setup effort.

Discovery affects findability only. Authorization still depends on password, identity, and seat availability.

docs.title: Server lease lifecycle
docs.text:
When a protected app launches on a client, the licensing runtime contacts the server and asks for authorization. The request identifies the product and the client; the server evaluates current seat availability and policy (access password, client identity, per-client limits). If the checks pass, the server issues a lease to that client.

While the app runs, the client renews its lease at intervals. Renewals are lightweight and tolerate brief network hiccups. A normal app exit releases the lease immediately. After crashes or power loss, the server reclaims the seat when the lease timeout elapses.

Denials map to clear categories:

  • Inventory: all seats are in use.
  • Policy: per-client limits or schedules block the request.
  • Authentication/identity: password missing/invalid or required identity not provided.
  • Eligibility: the product/version isn’t permitted for server leasing.
  • Topology: the initial request succeeds but renewals can’t round-trip due to routing, VPN, or firewall rules.

This lifecycle keeps license secrets in the server’s location (the attached dongle) and exposes only short-lived authorization to clients, enabling central control and audit without distributing licenses to endpoints.

docs.title: Identity, access, and audit
docs.text:
Identity, access, and audit sit above the licensing flows and describe who may connect and how usage is attributed.

An access password is the first gate: clients that know it can present themselves; others are rejected before any license logic runs. If the server requires client identity (typically a username, a machine name, or both), that identity is attached to each connection and lease, turning anonymous consumption into attributable activity. After admission, the server evaluates availability and per-client limits, issuing a time-bound lease or recording a denial with a reason. Audit is the record of these events (connections, leases, renewals, releases, denials), summarized into trends and peaks for planning and compliance. The trade-off is a small prompt at connection time in exchange for clear accountability and capacity signals.

Discovery (public or private) only affects how clients find the server; admission and attribution are controlled here.

docs.title: Network boundaries
docs.text:
Licensing relies on three layers: basic IP reachability to the server, the application TCP port used for authorization, and optional multicast DNS for public discovery. Public discovery is limited to a single subnet or VLAN. Private connections don’t use broadcast and work across routed networks and VPNs.

If the server’s TCP port is blocked by firewall settings, clients may see the server but can’t obtain leases. If multicast DNS is blocked, the Discovered list stays empty even though direct connections can succeed.

On VPNs, split tunneling, policy-based routing, or overlapping address space can interrupt lease renewals. Renewals are small and periodic, but persistent loss or jitter causes clients to drop and reconnect.

A compact way to reason about failures: confirm reachability first (routes, VPN, firewall), then admission policy (password, identity), then availability (seats, limits).

docs.title: Capacity and planning
docs.text:
Seats define concurrency. A pool of N seats allows up to N active leases at once. But demand is spiky, so planning focuses on peak simultaneous use rather than headcount or averages.

Server statistics help you plan by showing concurrent clients, denials, and time-of-day patterns. If denials cluster at peak times, you have two levers:

  • Increase capacity by adding seats.
  • Reduce peak demand with policy such as per-client caps, schedules, or faster seat recycling.

The right balance depends on cost, user impact, and how predictable your workload is.

docs.title: When a server fits
docs.text: A server fits when many people share the same products and you need central control, attribution, and predictable allocation. It assumes a stable LAN or a well-managed VPN, and seats stored on the server host’s dongle so clients can lease across the network. This model favors labs, classrooms, and studios that plan around peak concurrency and want audit trails.

docs.title: When individual licensing fits
docs.text: Individual licensing fits when work is mostly solo or mobile, or when connectivity is unreliable. A local dongle favors offline use and portability. A Cloud session favors always-online machines with minimal setup. Both avoid running a server and reduce operational overhead.

docs.title: Add a private server by IP address
docs.text:
When discovery is disabled or you’re connecting across VPNs/subnets, add the server directly by address. Use this when you can’t use a configuration file or need to target a specific host and port.

Goal

Connect to a private server by entering its IP/hostname and port in Acme License Hub.

docs.title: Before you start
docs.text: Confirm you have the server’s IP or hostname, the TCP port if your administrator specifies one, and the access password if required. Make sure the client can reach the server over the network (same LAN or a routed/VPN path).

docs.title: Steps
docs.text:
1. Open Acme License Hub on the client.
  2. Go to Servers → Add → By address.
  3. Enter the IP/hostname and port (if provided).
  4. Save and confirm the new entry under Private.
  5. Select the server and click Connect.
  6. Enter the access password if prompted.

Outcome

The server appears under Private and shows Connected without LAN discovery. You can launch protected software on the client machine without licensing errors.

docs.title: Add a private server with a config file
docs.text:
For private servers, the simplest and most reliable onboarding is importing a configuration file from your administrator. It avoids typos and locks in the correct settings.

Goal

Import a client configuration file so the Hub can connect to a private server.

docs.title: Before you start
docs.text: Get the configuration file from your administrator and, if required, the access password. Ensure the client machine can reach the server over the network (LAN or routed/VPN path).

docs.title: Steps
docs.text:
1. Open Acme License Hub on the client.
  2. Go to Servers → Add → Import configuration.
  3. Select the file from your administrator and confirm the new entry under Private.
  4. Select the server and click Connect.
  5. Enter the access password if prompted.

Outcome

The server appears under Private and shows Connected without LAN discovery. You can launch protected software on the client machine without licensing errors.

docs.title: See also
docs.text:

  • Make the server private
  • VPN and subnets
  • Firewalls

docs.title: Auto-connect to a public server
docs.text:
If your server advertises on the LAN, you can connect with a couple of clicks. This is the fastest path for workstations on the same subnet or broadcast domain.

Goal

Connect to a publicly discoverable server using the Hub’s Discovered list.

docs.title: Before you start
docs.text: Join the same subnet/VLAN as the server and get the access password from your administrator if required. If you’re remote or on a different subnet, use a private connection method instead.

docs.title: Steps
docs.text:
1. Open Acme License Hub and go to Servers.
  2. Under Discovered, select your server.
  3. Click Connect and provide the access password if prompted.

Outcome

The server shows Connected in the Hub and you can launch apps without licensing errors.

docs.text:

  • VPN and subnets

docs.title: Activate a license
docs.text:
To run a protected app, move the license from your account to an Acme dongle or Acme Cloud session.

This guide is for activating a license for local use. To serve shared licenses over a network, see Allocate seats to a USB on the server. No activation is required at the client machine, but it must be connected to the server host.

Goal

Move a license from your account to a chosen location.

docs.title: Before you start
docs.text: Sign in to Acme License Hub. Decide where you want the license to live: an Acme dongle (connect it directly to a USB port) or Acme Cloud session (ensure internet access).

docs.title: Steps
docs.text:
1. In Acme License Hub, find the license under Available.
  2. Click Activate.
  3. Choose a location: Acme dongle or Acme Cloud session (if supported).
  4. Confirm and wait for activation to complete.

Outcome

The license appears at the selected location and is ready for use by your apps.

docs.title: See also
docs.text:
• Deactivate a license
  • Start or end a Cloud session
  • Repair an Acme dongle
  • Allocate seats to a USB on the server

docs.title: Deactivate a license
docs.text:
Return a license to your account so you can move it to another location.

This guide is for deactivating a license from a location connected to your machine. You don’t need to deactivate licenses shared from a license server. Closing the protected app automatically releases the seat.

Goal

Move a license from its current location back to your account.

docs.title: Before you start
docs.text: Close any protected apps that might be using the license, then sign in to Acme License Hub so the change can complete cleanly.

docs.title: Steps
docs.text:
1. Find the license in its current location (Acme dongle or cloud session).
  2. Choose Deactivate.
  3. Confirm and wait for completion.

Outcome

The license appears under Available in your account and can be activated elsewhere.

docs.title: See also
docs.text:
• Activate a license
  • Transfer a license

docs.title: Redeem an activation code
docs.text:
Claim a new license by adding it to your account with the code provided by your vendor.

Goal

Add a new license to your account using an activation code.

docs.title: Before you start
docs.text: Sign in to Acme License Hub and have the activation code ready.

docs.title: Steps
docs.text:
1. In the Hub, choose Redeem.
  2. Enter the activation code exactly as provided.
  3. Submit and confirm the license appears under Available.

Outcome

The license is added to your account and ready to activate to a location.

docs.title: See also
docs.text: • Activate a license

docs.title: Repair an Acme dongle
docs.text:
Fix common issues with the USB key before filing a replacement claim.

Goal

Resolve typical dongle errors by synchronizing and reinitializing connections.

docs.title: Before you start
docs.text: Connect the Acme dongle directly to the computer (avoid multiport USB adapters). Open Acme License Hub and sign in.

docs.title: Steps
docs.text:
1. In the Hub, right-click the dongle and choose Synchronize.
  2. If the issue persists, move the dongle to a different USB port and repeat Synchronize.
  3. If still failing, try another machine to rule out local USB issues.
  4. If the dongle isn’t detected at all, reseat it and check OS-level USB/device settings.

Outcome

Most state or connection issues clear after a successful synchronization or port change; the dongle and licenses appear correctly in the Hub.

docs.title: See also
docs.text:
• File a Return Authorization
  • Acme License Hub errors

docs.title: File a return authorization
docs.text:
Replace a broken, lost, or stolen Acme dongle through Acme’s service process.

Goal

Submit a Return Authorization request for hardware replacement.

docs.title: Before you start
docs.text: Gather the dongle’s serial number and any proof-of-purchase your support team might request. If the dongle still appears in the Hub, try a quick Synchronize first.

docs.title: Steps
docs.text:
1. Sign in to your account on the Acme website.
  2. Open Support → Returns/RA.
  3. Choose Broken, Lost, or Stolen.
  4. Fill in the requested details and submit the request.
  5. If instructed, package and ship the device to the provided address.

Outcome

You receive confirmation and tracking for the Return Authorization. Replacement processing begins per the selected case type.

docs.title: See also
docs.text: • Repair an Acme dongle

docs.title: Start or end a Cloud session
Start or end a Cloud session
docs.text:
Make Cloud-enabled licenses available on this machine while you’re signed in. Use this when you don’t have a dongle attached or prefer cloud-based access.

Goal

Open or close an Acme License Cloud session in the Hub.

docs.title: Before you start
docs.text: Sign in to Acme License Hub and confirm your account includes Cloud-enabled licenses. Ensure the machine has a stable internet connection.

docs.title: Steps
docs.text:
1. To start: in the Hub menu, choose Open Cloud Session and wait for the status to show Open.
  2. If the license for your protected app doesn’t automatically move to the cloud session, activate it there.
  3. Run your protected app while the session remains open.
  4. To end: return to the Hub and choose Close Cloud Session; confirm the status shows Closed.

Outcome

While the session is Open, Cloud-enabled licenses are available to your apps. Closing the session releases them.

docs.title: See also
docs.text:
• Start your first Acme License Cloud session
  • Acme License Hub errors

docs.title: Transfer a license
docs.text:
Move a license from your account to another user’s account. This is useful for resale or handoff to a teammate.

Goal

Send a license to another Acme account.

docs.title: Before you start
docs.text:
Warning

License transfers are irreversible. Make sure you have the correct Acme account for the recipient.

Confirm the product is eligible for transfer and understand any fees. Get the recipient’s Acme account ID and ensure the license isn’t activated to an Acme dongle or cloud session.

docs.title: Steps
docs.text:
1. In Acme License Hub, select the license in your account.
  2. Choose Transfer.
  3. Enter the recipient’s Acme account ID.
  4. Review any fees and confirm the transfer.

Outcome

The license leaves your account and appears in the recipient’s account, ready for activation.

docs.title: See also
docs.text: • Deactivate a license

docs.title: Allocate seats to a USB on the server
docs.text:
To share licenses across a network, seats must be on the Acme dongle attached to the server host. This places the entitlements where the server can grant leases to clients.

Goal

Activate a license to the Acme dongle on the server host so clients can lease seats over the network.

docs.title: Before you start
docs.text: On the server host, connect an Acme dongle directly to a USB port (avoid multiport USB adapters). Open Acme License Hub and sign in with the account that holds the license.

docs.title: Steps
docs.text:
1. In Acme License Hub, find the license under Available.
  2. Choose Activate and select the Acme dongle as the target.

Outcome

The license appears on the server’s Acme dongle and is available for clients to lease via the server.

docs.title: See also
docs.text: • No seats available

docs.title: Export a client configuration file
docs.text:
When your server is private (discovery disabled) or clients connect across VPNs/subnets, the fastest, least-error-prone way to onboard users is a client configuration file. It packages the connection details your users need, so they can import once in the Hub and connect without typing addresses or ports.

Use this when you want predictable, repeatable client setup, especially in labs or managed environments.

Goal

Create a file clients can import to connect to your private server.

docs.title: Before you start
docs.text: Confirm the server shows Online in Server Admin and you have the current access password.

docs.title: Steps
docs.text:
1. Open Server Admin on the server host.
  2. Go to Client access or Connections.
  3. Select Export client configuration.
  4. Save the file and share it securely with users.

Outcome

Clients can import the file in Acme License Hub and connect without discovery or manual addressing.

docs.title: See also
docs.text:
• Client setup: Add a private server with a config file
  • Serveradministrator: Make the server private

docs.title: Make the server private
docs.text:
Hide your server from LAN discovery so only users with the details you provide can connect. Use this in managed networks, across VPNs/subnets, or any time you want explicit control over who can find the server.

Goal

Disable LAN discovery and require clients to connect by configuration file or address.

docs.title: Before you start
docs.text: Sign in to Server Admin with administrator rights. Decide whether you’ll distribute a client configuration file or the server address and port, and make sure you have the current access password ready to share securely.

docs.title: Steps
docs.text:
1. Open Server Admin.
  2. Go to Discovery.
  3. Turn off Advertise on local network.
  4. Apply changes.
  5. Share a client configuration file or the server address (and password) with users.

Outcome

The server no longer appears under Discovered in the Hub; users connect using the file or address you provide.

docs.title: See also
docs.text:
• Export a client configuration file
  • Connect a client to a private server

docs.title: Require client identity
docs.text:
Capture who is using seats by requiring each client to present an identity at connection time. Use this for auditing, per-user limits, or when you need accountability in shared labs.

Goal

Enforce client identity collection during connection for auditing and control.

docs.title: Before you start
docs.text: Sign in to Server Admin with administrator rights. Decide which identity you’ll require (username, machine name, or both) and how you’ll communicate that to users (for example, in onboarding notes or a config file).

docs.title: Steps
docs.text:
1. Open Server Admin.
  2. Go to Access control or Identity.
  3. Enable Require client identity.
  4. Choose the identity source (username, machine name, or both).
  5. Apply changes.

Outcome

Clients must present identity during connection; identities appear in statistics and logs for auditing.

docs.title: See also
docs.text:
• View server statistics
  • Require a server password

docs.title: Require a server password
docs.text:
Protect your license server by requiring a password for every client connection. Use this when your server is publicly discoverable on the LAN or whenever you want to prevent unauthorized access, even on private servers.

Goal

Enforce an access password so only authorized clients can connect.

docs.title: Before you start
docs.text: Sign in to Server Admin with administrator rights.

docs.title: Steps
docs.text:
1. Open Server Admin.
  2. Go to Access control.
  3. Enable Require password.
  4. Set and confirm a strong password.
  5. Apply changes.

Outcome

New and existing clients must authenticate with the access password before connecting.

docs.title: See also
docs.text:
• Require client identity
  • Export a client configuration file

docs.title: View server statistics
docs.text:
Use Server Admin to see who is connected, which products are in use, and where clients are being denied. This helps with capacity planning, auditing, and resolving “can’t get a seat” reports.

Goal

Monitor leases, clients, and license usage to spot peaks and denials.

docs.title: Before you start
docs.text: Sign in to Server Admin with administrator rights. If you’re investigating a complaint, note the approximate time and product involved so you can focus your review.

docs.title: Steps
docs.text:
1. Open Server Admin.
  2. Go to Statistics or Status.

  3. Review the key indicators:

    • Online/Offline state of the server
    • Active clients currently connected
    • Active leases and recent lease history/denials
    • License usage by product (peaks and trends)

Outcome

You can identify peak usage periods, see which products consume seats, and pinpoint blocked clients or denials.

docs.title: See also
docs.text:
• Require client identity
  • No seats available

docs.title: Glossary
docs.text:
Account

Your identity for Acme License services.

Acme dongle

Hardware key that holds licenses.

Acme License Engine

System components required by the Hub and protected apps.

Acme License Hub

Desktop app for managing your license activations.

Activation

Moving a license to a location.

Cloud session

A signed-in state that makes Cloud-enabled licenses available.

Client

A workstation that connects to a server for seats.

Client configuration file

A file that defines how to reach a private server.

Deactivation

Returning a license to your account.

Discovery

How clients find public servers on the LAN.

Lease

A time-bound grant for a client to use a seat.

License

A product entitlement in your account.

Private server

A server that doesn’t advertise on the LAN.

Public server

A server that advertises on the LAN for auto-discovery.

Seat

One concurrent use of a license.

Server

The service that grants seats to clients.

Server Admin

The administrator UI for the server.

Synchronization

Refresh action for an Acme dongle to fix state issues.

docs.title: See also
docs.text: • Architecture

docs.title: Acme License Hub UI and icon legend
docs.text: This page maps common areas in the Hub and summarizes icons.

docs.title: UI map
docs.text:
• Locations: Acme dongle, Server, Cloud
  • Licenses: Products, Versions, Seats
  • Actions: Activate, Deactivate, Transfer, Redeem, Synchronize

docs.title: Icons
docs.text: Icon Meaning  (Key) License or seat present  (Cloud on) (Cloud off) Cloud session status  (USB) (USB-C) Physical dongle present  (Warning) Action required or error

docs.title: Server Admin settings
docs.text: All fields available in the server UI. Names may vary slightly by version.

docs.title: Identity and access
docs.text:
• Server name: label shown to clients.
  • Require password: force authentication for every connection.
  • Require client identity: collect user/machine info.

docs.title: Discovery
docs.text:
• Advertise on local network: enable discovery.
  • Public / Private: toggle broadcast vs manual connect.
  • Port: TCP port used for client connections.

docs.title: Licensing
docs.text:
• Active licenses: seats allocated to the server.
  • Seat timeout / lease period: how long idle clients keep a seat.
  • Max leases per client: cap concurrent usage.

docs.title: Monitoring
docs.text:
• Status: online/offline, uptime.
  • Statistics: active clients, leases over time, denials.
  • Logs: connection and error logs with timestamps.

docs.title: Files
docs.text:
• Export client configuration: generate a file for private servers.
  • Backup / restore settings: save and load server config.

docs.title: System requirements
docs.text: Use supported OS versions and hardware that meets your protected apps’ needs.

docs.title: Operating systems
docs.text:
• Windows: all releases currently supported by Microsoft.
  • macOS: all releases currently supported by Apple.
  • Linux: not supported unless a product vendor states otherwise.

docs.title: Network
docs.text:
• Reliable LAN for server and clients.
  • Bonjour/mDNS for discovery on public servers.
  • Open TCP port used by the server.

docs.title: See also
docs.text:
• Install Acme License Engine and Hub
  • Firewalls

docs.title: Server not discovered
docs.text: The server doesn’t appear under Discovered in the Hub.

docs.title: Confirm
docs.text:
• Server is Online in Server Admin.
  • Client and server are on the same subnet.
  • Discovery is set to Public on the server.

docs.title: Likely causes and fixes
docs.text:
1. Bonjour/mDNS blocked or absent Install or enable mDNS on the client OS. Allow mDNS through host firewall rules.
  2. Different subnets or VLANs Discovery is broadcast-limited. Use a private server connection across subnets.
  3. Host firewall rules Allow the server’s TCP port and mDNS on both ends. See Firewalls.
  4. Server offline Restart the service on the host.
  5. Name conflicts Rename the server to a unique name and retry.

docs.title: See also
docs.text:
• Auto-connect to a public server
  • VPN and subnets

docs.title: Firewalls
docs.text: Connections fail or drop due to filtering.

docs.title: Confirm
docs.text:
• Clients can ping the server host.
  • Server port and mDNS are open on both host and client.

docs.title: Likely causes and fixes
docs.text:
1. Third-party security suites Add allow rules or disable for a test.
  2. Host firewall blocks Allow inbound TCP on the server’s port. Allow mDNS. Create outbound rules on clients.
  3. Corporate firewall or segmentation Use a private server connection and open the server port between subnets.

docs.title: See also
docs.text:
• Server not discovered
  • Add a private server by IP address

docs.title: Acme License Hub errors
docs.text: Resolve common errors in the Hub.

docs.title: Confirm
docs.text:
• You have the latest Acme License Engine installed.
  • The machine has a stable network connection.

docs.title: Common errors and fixes
docs.text:
• Windows error 60000: Uninstall and reinstall Acme License Engine. See Install Acme License Engine and Hub.
  • Sign-in failed: check time, date, and DNS; retry after network is stable.
  • Cloud session failed to open: sign out, restart the Hub, and try again.

docs.title: See also
docs.text:
• Start or end a Cloud session
  • Repair an Acme dongle

docs.title: No seats available
docs.text: Clients connect but get a denial due to lack of seats.

docs.title: Confirm
docs.text:
• The license is allocated to the Server.
  • The number of active leases matches the seat count.
  • Client appears under Connections or Statistics.

docs.title: Likely causes and fixes
docs.text:
1. All seats in use Deactivate on idle machines or add seats.
  2. Per-client limits Increase the max leases per client in Server Admin.
  3. Lease not released Wait for timeout or restart the client machine.
  4. Wrong license location Move the seat from machine or Cloud to an Acme dongle attached to the Server.

docs.title: See also
docs.text:
• Allocate seats to a USB on the server
  • View server statistics

docs.title: App version unsupported
docs.text: A protected app can’t use sharable licenses due to version limits.

docs.title: Confirm
docs.text:
• The vendor’s release notes list support for sharable licenses.
  • The app version on the client matches or exceeds the minimum.

docs.title: Likely causes and fixes
docs.text:
1. Old app build Update the app to a version that supports sharable licenses.
  2. Mixed plugin versions Update all related plugins to compatible builds.
  3. Runtime mismatch Reinstall Acme License Engine on the client.

docs.title: See also
docs.text: • System requirements

docs.title: VPN and subnets
docs.text: Clients on VPN or different subnets can’t see or reach the server.

docs.title: Confirm
docs.text:
• Client can reach the server IP with ping or traceroute.
  • The server is reachable on its TCP port from the client network.

docs.title: Likely causes and fixes
docs.text:
1. mDNS doesn’t cross subnets Use a private server connection or configure a discovery proxy.
  2. VPN split tunneling Disable split tunneling or add routes to the server LAN.
  3. Blocked ports Open the server’s TCP port across the VPN.
  4. NAT or address overlap Use unique address ranges and proper routes.

docs.title: See also
docs.text:
• Add a private server by IP address
  • Firewalls

docs.title: Connect a client to a private server
Connect a client to a private server
docs.text:
Time: ~10 minutes

What you’ll accomplish

A client connected to a private Acme license server using a configuration file (recommended for first-time setup).

You need

  • Acme License Hub installed on the client
  • A client configuration file from your administrator
  • The server’s access password (if required)
  • Network reachability to the server (same LAN or routed/VPN)

docs.title: Step 1: Get server details
docs.text:
1. Obtain the client configuration file from your administrator.
  2. Ensure the server is Online (ask your administrator if unsure).

docs.title: Step 2: Import the configuration (recommended)
docs.text:
1. Open Acme License Hub on the client.
  2. Go to Servers → Add → Import configuration.
  3. Select the file from your administrator.

The server entry now appears under Private.

docs.title: Step 3: Connect
docs.text:
1. Select the server under Private and click Connect.
  2. Enter the access password if prompted.

The server entry now shows Connected.

docs.title: Step 4: Prove access
docs.text:
1. Launch a protected app on the client.
  2. Confirm the app starts without a license error.

Success

The app runs and the server remains Connected in the Hub.

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
• Can’t connect or times out → check routes/VPN and open paths. See VPN and subnets and Firewalls.
  • Server entry missing after import → the file is invalid or stale. Ask your administrator for a fresh configuration.
  • Password prompt fails → confirm the current access password with your administrator.

docs.title: Next steps
docs.text:
• How-to → Export a client configuration file
  • How-to → Add a private server by IP address

docs.title: Start your first Acme Cloud session
Start your first Acme License Cloud session
docs.text:
Time: ~5 minutes

What you’ll accomplish

Open an Acme License Cloud session in the Hub and run a protected app while the session is active.

You need

  • Acme License Hub installed
  • Internet access
  • Cloud-enabled licenses in your account

docs.title: Step 1: Sign in
docs.text:
1. Open Acme License Hub.
  2. Sign in with your Acme account.

docs.title: Step 2: Open a Cloud session
docs.text:
1. In the Hub menu, choose Open Cloud Session.
  2. Wait for the status to update.

The session status now shows Open and Cloud-enabled licenses are in it.

docs.title: Step 3: Run a protected app
docs.text: 1. Launch your protected app while the session is open and confirm that it runs without licensing errors.

docs.title: Step 4: Close the Cloud session
docs.text:
1. Return to the Hub.
  2. Choose Close Cloud Session.

The session status now shows Closed.

Success

The app runs while the Cloud session is open. Closing the session releases all licenses.

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
• Sign-in or connectivity errors → see Acme License Hub errors.
  • App still shows a license error → in the Hub, confirm your license is Cloud-enabled and that the Cloud session status is Open.

docs.title: Next steps
docs.text:
• Activate a license
  • Deactivate a license

docs.title: Install Acme License Engine and Hub
Install Acme License Engine and Hub
docs.text:
Time: ~15 minutes

What you’ll accomplish

Install the Acme License Engine components and the Acme License Hub, then sign in.

You need

  • Administrator rights on the machine
  • Internet access
  • An Acme account

docs.title: Step 1: Get the installer
docs.text:
1. Download the latest Acme License Engine installer for your OS from the official site.
  2. Verify the file finished downloading before you proceed.

docs.title: Step 2: Prepare the system
docs.text:
1. Close all licensed apps.
  2. Save work and quit other installers.

docs.title: Step 3: Install Engine and Hub
docs.text:
Tip

If your OS blocks components the first time, open Security & Privacy and click Allow, then rerun the installer.

  1. Run the installer with administrator privileges.
  2. Select Acme License Engine and Acme License Hub.
  3. Accept any security prompts.
  4. Finish the install and restart the machine if prompted.

docs.title: Step 4: Sign in to verify
docs.text:
1. Open Acme License Hub.
  2. Sign in with your Acme account.
  3. Confirm you can reach your account data.

Success

The Hub shows your account name and no connectivity errors.

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text: • Installer completed but the Hub won’t open or errors appear → see Engine and Hub errors.

docs.title: Next steps
docs.text:
• Activate a license
  • Set up your first Acme license server

docs.title: Set up your first Acme license server
Set up your first Acme license server
docs.text:
Time: ~15 minutes

What you’ll accomplish

A single Acme License server on a LAN with one client leasing a seat from an Acme dongle attached to the server host.

You need

  • Admin rights on both machines
  • Stable LAN (wired preferred)
  • Windows or macOS host for the server that stays powered on
  • Acme License Engine and Acme License Hub installed on the server host
  • Acme dongle plugged into the server host (avoid multiport USB adapters)
  • One license with sharable seats in your account

docs.title: Step 1: Start and name the server
docs.text:
1. On the server host, open Server Admin.
  2. Give the server a unique name.
  3. Set a strong access password and save.

The server is now identified and protected.

docs.title: Step 2: Enable discovery for the first run
docs.text:
1. In Server Admin → Discovery, set Public (advertise on LAN).
  2. Apply changes.

The server is now visible on the LAN.

docs.title: Step 3: Activate seats to the server’s dongle
docs.text:
Warning

For server leasing, seats must be activated to the Acme dongle attached to the server host, not to another location.

  1. Ensure the Acme dongle is connected directly to the server host.
  2. On the server host, open Acme License Hub and sign in.
  3. Find your license under Available.
  4. Choose Activate and target the dongle.
  5. Wait for activation to complete.

License seats are now present on the server’s dongle.

docs.title: Step 4: Verify status
docs.text:
1. In Server Admin, open Status or Statistics and confirm Online.
  2. In Acme License Hub on the server host, confirm the license appears on the Acme dongle.

docs.title: Step 5: Connect a client on the same subnet
docs.text:
1. On a client machine, open Acme License Hub → Servers.
  2. Under Discovered, select your server and click Connect.
  3. Enter the access password if prompted.
  4. Confirm that the server entry shows Connected.

docs.title: Step 6: Prove a lease
docs.text:
1. On the client, launch a protected app.
  2. In Server Admin → Statistics, confirm 1 active lease.

Success

The app launches without errors, and the server shows an active lease while the app runs.

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
• Server not listed under Discovered → see Server not discovered.
  • Client connects but no seats → seats may be on the wrong location. Ensure activation targeted the Acme dongle on the server host. See No seats available.
  • Connection blocked → see Firewalls.

docs.title: Next steps
docs.text:
• Export a client configuration file
  • Make the server private
  • Require client identity

docs.title: How-to: Add authors to a TDU project
docs.text:
Use this procedure to add the authors who will work on a TDU project. This controls which names you can assign documents to in the document plan.

Goal

Maintain an accurate list of authors for the project using consistent identifiers.

docs.title: Before you start
docs.text:
Confirm that you have:

  • A list of authors assigned to the project.
  • Each author’s identifier in firstname.lastname format.

docs.title: Steps
docs.text:
1. Open the project and go to the Metadata tab.
  2. Locate the Author field list.
  3. For each author assigned to the project, add a new Author entry.
  4. For each entry, enter the identifier in firstname.lastname format.
  5. Review the list and remove any duplicates or outdated entries.
  6. Save the project.

Note: Use the same identifier format that appears in your other systems so you can match reporting later without clean-up work.

Outcome

The project has a clean author list made up of current team members, using consistent identifiers.

docs.title: See also
docs.text:
• How-to: Configure TDU project metadata
  • How-to: Import or create a TDU document plan

docs.title: How-to: Annotate TDU source documents
docs.text:
Use this procedure when you need to mark up source files in TDU so you can see which parts of a source support specific documents or topics.

Goal

Add annotations to source documents that are linked to entries in the document plan.

docs.title: Before you start
docs.text:
Confirm that you have:

  • Configured the Central Data Path and built the source list.
  • Imported or created the document plan.
  • Any needed correlations between documents and sources, if your team uses them.

docs.title: Steps
docs.text:
1. Open the project and go to the Sources tab.
  2. Locate the source file you want to annotate.
  3. Double click the source entry, or select it and click Open for annotation.
  4. In the source viewer, navigate to the section you want to mark.
  5. Select the relevant text or area.
  6. Click Add annotation.

  7. In the annotation dialog:

    • Choose the related document from the Document drop down list.
    • Optionally, choose an annotation type such as Requirement, Procedure, or Background.
    • Enter a short note that explains what this section covers.
    • Click Save annotation.
    • Repeat steps 5 to 8 for each additional section you need to annotate.
    • When you finish, click Save or close the viewer if it saves automatically.

Outcome

The source file now contains saved annotations, each linked to specific documents or topics in the document plan.

docs.title: See also
docs.text:
• How-to: Correlate source data to TDU documents
  • How-to: Build the TDU source list
  • How-to: Start a TDU document from the plan

docs.title: How-to: Build the TDU source list
docs.text:
Use this procedure to tell TDU which source files are in scope for a project. TDU scans the central data folder and builds a source list you can refer to while planning and writing.

Goal

Create an up-to-date source list for the project based on the central data folder.

docs.title: Before you start
docs.text:
Confirm that you have:

  • Completed metadata configuration for Central Data Path.
  • All cleaned, annotation-ready source files in the central data folder.
  • Access to a workstation with enough processing capacity for the size of the project.

docs.title: Steps
docs.text:
1. Open the project and confirm the Central Data Path in the Metadata tab points to the correct folder.
  2. Go to the Sources tab.
  3. Click Create source list.

  4. Wait while TDU scans the Central Data Path and builds the list.

    • For large projects, avoid running other resource-intensive tasks during this step.
    • When the scan completes, confirm that the list contains one entry per source file in scope.
    • If entries are missing or unexpected files appear, correct the Central Data Path or the files in that folder, then run Create source list again.

Outcome

The Sources tab shows a complete source list that matches the cleaned source files for the project.

docs.title: See also
docs.text:
• How-to: Configure TDU project metadata
  • How-to: Refresh the TDU source list when source files change

docs.title: How-to: Configure TDU project metadata
docs.text:
Use this procedure after you open a TDU project. You will connect the project to the correct master record and working folders so documents and reports line up with your real project.

Goal

Configure the project metadata so TDU uses the correct master record and data paths.

docs.title: Before you start
docs.text:
Warning

Get explicit agreement from your project lead if you plan to reuse any existing data paths.

Get the official Master Record ID for this project, and the network paths for both the source files and the production document output.

docs.title: Steps
docs.text:
1. In your open project, go to the Metadata tab.

  2. In Master Record ID, enter the official ID from your project-tracking system.

    Tip

    If you are not sure which ID to use, pause here and confirm it. Reports roll up to this record.

  3. Warning

    If multiple projects share a data location, confirm that you are using the correct folder for this project before saving.

    In Sources, enter or browse to the folder that holds the source files for this project.

  4. In Documents, enter or browse to the project’s documents folder.

    • TDU creates documents here by copying and renaming the appropriate templates.
  5. Save the project.

Outcome

The project metadata is saved. The master record and all working paths point to the correct locations for this project.

docs.title: See also
docs.text:
• How-to: Open or create a TDU project
  • How-to: Build the TDU source list
  • How-to: Verify TDU reporting inputs

docs.title: How-to: Correlate source data to TDU documents
docs.text:
Use this procedure to link each document in the plan to the source files it relies on. Correlation keeps coverage and traceability reports meaningful.

Goal

Associate each document plan entry with the correct source files from the project source list.

docs.title: Before you start
docs.text:
Confirm that you have:

  • Configured the Central Data Path and built the source list.
  • Imported or created the document plan.
  • A clear idea which source files support each document.

docs.title: Steps
docs.text:
1. Open the project and go to the Document Plan tab.
  2. Locate the document row you want to correlate.
  3. In the Sources column for that row, click the link or button, or right click the row and choose Edit sources.

  4. In the Select sources dialog, review the list of available source files.

    • Use filters or search to narrow the list by file name or folder if needed.
    • Select the checkboxes for each source file that contributes to this document.
    • Click OK or Apply to save the correlation.
    • Back in the Document Plan tab, confirm that the Sources column now shows the updated count or list of linked sources.
    • Repeat for other documents that need source correlations.

If a required source file does not appear in the list, check that it is present in the central data folder and that the source list has been rebuilt. Then repeat this procedure.

Outcome

Each document plan entry is linked to the relevant source files, and the document plan shows those correlations.

docs.title: See also
docs.text:
• How-to: Build the TDU source list
  • How-to: Annotate TDU source documents
  • How-to: Verify TDU reporting inputs

docs.title: How-to: Import or create a TDU document plan
docs.text:
Use this procedure to set up or update the document plan for a project. You can either import an existing plan from a spreadsheet or build it directly in TDU.

Goal

Populate the Document Plan tab with the documents, types, and assignments for the project.

docs.title: Before you start
docs.text:
Confirm that you have:

  • An initial document plan in Excel or another planning tool, or a clear list of documents you need to create.
  • The agreed column mapping if you plan to import from .xlsx, .xls, or .csv.
  • Author identifiers in firstname.lastname format for any documents you plan to assign.

docs.title: Option A. Import a plan for a larger project
docs.text:
1. Open the plan in Excel or your planning tool.
  2. Export the plan to .xlsx, .xls, or .csv using the column mapping agreed with your tools team.
  3. In TDU, open the project and go to the Document Plan tab.
  4. Import the exported file.

  5. Review the imported entries:

    • Confirm titles, types, and statuses look correct.
    • Confirm author assignments use the expected identifiers.
    • Fix any mapping or formatting issues you see, then save the project.

docs.title: Option B. Create or extend a plan for a smaller project
docs.text:
1. In TDU, open the project and go to the Document Plan tab.
  2. Right-click in the document list.
  3. Choose Add Chapter, Add Subject, or Add Task as needed.
  4. For each new entry, enter the document details, including title, type, any author assignments, and status.
  5. Repeat for each document you need to add.
  6. Save the project.

Note: Keep document types and status values consistent with your team’s conventions so reports stay readable.

Outcome

The Document Plan tab lists the planned documents for the project with correct types, statuses, and any initial assignments.

docs.title: See also
docs.text:
• How-to: Add authors to a TDU project
  • How-to: Verify TDU reporting inputs

docs.title: How-to: Open or create a TDU project
docs.text:
Use this procedure when you need to start work on a real project in Tech Doc Utility (TDU). You will either open a shell project that exists already or create a new one so you can configure it.

Goal

Open a TDU project in its own tab so you can configure metadata, authors, sources, and the document plan.

docs.title: Before you start
docs.text: Make sure TDU is visible in the Acme system tray, and get the project name your team expects you to use.

docs.title: Steps
docs.text:
1. Launch TDU from the Acme system tray.

  2. On the startup page, do one of the following:

    • To start a new project, click New project and enter a clear project name.
    • To use a shell project, select it from the list and click Open.

  3. Confirm that the project opens in its own tab.

  4. Check the project name in the tab header. Make sure it matches the project you intend to configure.

Outcome

You have a TDU project open in its own tab and are ready to configure it.

docs.title: See also
docs.text:
• How-to: Configure TDU project metadata
  • How-to: Add authors to a TDU project

docs.title: Tech Doc Utility
docs.text:
Tech Doc Utility (TDU) is an internal desktop workspace for documentation projects. It sits on top of your existing systems and gives authors, editors, and leads a single place to see what they are making, why they are making it, and which inputs each document depends on. Instead of juggling spreadsheets, shared folders, and tool specific dashboards, you get one project view that knows about your source data, document plan, and production folders.

TDU does not replace your authoring tools, source control, or time tracking. It connects to them and keeps the project view in sync with the work that is actually happening.

docs.title: When to use TDU
docs.text:
Use TDU when you need to deliver a body of documentation that draws from shared research and shared infrastructure, for example when you need to:

  • Manage a multi document project that reuses the same interview notes, specs, or logs across many deliverables.
  • Coordinate work across multiple authors, templates, or teams that share the same production folders.
  • Track project progress, document states, and dependencies in a way that survives handoffs and staff changes.
  • Publish review-ready PDFs to known locations without everyone maintaining their own file paths and shortcuts.

It works best in environments where project data, templates, and time tracking already live in shared systems and network locations, and you want one interface that understands all of them. If you currently rely on a mix of spreadsheets, personal checklists, and hallway updates to answer “what is the status of this project”, TDU gives you a single place to look instead.

For very small efforts, such as a single author producing one or two short documents without shared research or handoffs, the setup overhead might not be worth it. In those cases, local files and simple checklists are usually enough.

docs.title: How it fits into your workflow
docs.text:
A project in TDU is a container for everything you need to deliver a set of documents to a customer.

At a high level, each project in TDU:

  • Connects to a central master record so burnup and burndown reports match what the rest of the organization sees.
  • Points to one or more source data folders that hold the inputs you use to create documents.
  • Maintains a document plan that defines every deliverable, its owner, and its current status.
  • Tracks correlations between source data and planned documents so you can see what evidence supports which content.
  • Produces reports that summarize project completion, document status, correlation coverage, and document dependencies.

You still draft content in your usual tools. The project view in TDU tells you which documents exist, where they live, who owns them, and which research files they depend on. When a spec changes or a log file is updated, you can see which documents might be affected instead of relying on memory.

docs.title: Planning and structure
docs.text:
The planning views keep the document list, ownership, and status in one place. You see the set of deliverables for the project, who is responsible for each one, and how they relate to one another.

Use the planning views to:

  • Define the document plan for the project.
  • Keep the plan up to date as scope changes.
  • Align document statuses with your team workflow.
  • Capture relationships between documents that share inputs or content.

This gives authors and leads a shared reference for what exists and where work is currently focused.

docs.title: Research data and correlation
docs.text:
The research views give you a project level view of the source material behind your documents. Instead of navigating individual folders, you work with a single list that represents the inputs you care about.

Within a project, you can:

  • Register the main research sources for the project.
  • Link research items to planned documents.
  • See which material has not yet been linked to any document.

These links provide a visible connection between evidence and content. When a key input changes, you can trace which documents may need attention.

docs.title: Authoring and production
docs.text:
The authoring and production views focus on the files that authors and editors use in their daily work. Each document in the plan can be connected to a working file and to related production tasks.

From the authoring and production views, you can:

  • Create starting files for new documents from common patterns.
  • Associate documents with owners and working locations.
  • Record illustration or other requests for specific documents.
  • Open external tools.
  • Publish finished documents for review.

This keeps the connection between the document plan and the working files so you don’t have to track file locations and responsibilities separately.

docs.title: Reporting and visibility
docs.text:
The reporting views summarize the state of the project based on the plan and the links between documents and research. Reports use the same underlying data that authors and leads work with elsewhere in the project.

Reports cover:

  • Overall project completion and per document status.
  • How research material and documents relate at a project level.
  • Dependencies between documents inside the project.

These reports let project members and stakeholders review progress and coverage without exporting data to another tool.

docs.title: How-to: Start a TDU document from the plan
docs.text:
Use this procedure when you are ready to turn a planned item in the document plan into a working document file. You will create the file from the correct template in the project production folder.

Goal

Create a new working document from a document plan entry in the project’s production folder.

docs.title: Before you start
docs.text:
Confirm that you have:

  • Configured the project metadata, including Production Path and any required templates.
  • Imported or created the document plan entry you want to start.
  • An assigned author for the document, if your team expects one before work begins.

docs.title: Steps
docs.text:
1. Open the project and go to the Document Plan tab.

  2. Locate the row for the document you want to start.

    • Confirm that the title, type, and any author assignment are correct.

    • Check the Status for the document.

    • If your team uses a Planned status, set the status to Planned before you start.

    • With the document row selected, click Start document on the toolbar, or right click the row and choose Start document from template.

    • In the confirmation dialog, review:

    • The template that will be used.

    • The destination folder, which should match the Production Path.
    • Click Create.

    • After the operation completes, confirm that:

    • The document row now shows a Document Path or similar field populated.

    • A new file appears in the production folder with the expected name.
    • To begin writing, double click the row or use Open document to open the file in your authoring tool.

If you see an error about the production folder or missing templates, cancel the operation, fix the project metadata or template configuration, then repeat these steps.

Outcome

The selected document plan entry now has a corresponding working file in the production folder, created from the agreed template.

docs.title: How-to: Change status and assign TDU documents
docs.text:
Use this procedure to keep document status and ownership current in the document plan. Accurate status and assignments keep reporting and work queues reliable.

Goal

Update document statuses and author assignments in the document plan so they match current work.

docs.title: Before you start
docs.text:
Confirm that you have:

  • A current document plan for the project.
  • The list of authors who should own each document, with their firstname.lastname identifiers.
  • Agreement on the status values your team uses, such as Planned, In progress, Review, Approved.

docs.title: Update a single document
docs.text:
1. Open the project and go to the Document Plan tab.
  2. Locate the document row you want to update.
  3. To change status, click in the Status cell and select the new status from the drop down list.
  4. To change the assigned author, click in the Author cell and select the correct firstname.lastname from the list.
  5. Confirm that the row now shows the expected status and author.
  6. Save the project.

docs.title: Update several documents at once
docs.text:
1. In the Document Plan tab, select all rows you want to update.
  2. To bulk change status, use Set status on the toolbar or context menu and choose the new status.
  3. To bulk assign an author, use Assign author and choose the correct firstname.lastname.
  4. Spot check a few rows to make sure the changes applied as expected.
  5. Save the project.

If you cannot change a status, for example from Approved back to In progress, your project may restrict that transition. In that case, follow your team’s escalation process or ask your project lead to update the status.

Outcome

Document plan entries show up to date statuses and author assignments that match the actual work.

docs.title: Tutorial: Create your first TDU project
docs.text:
Time: ~30 minutes

What you’ll accomplish

Install Tech Doc Utility (TDU) and create a simple project with a basic document plan and source list.

You need

  • A Windows 7 or later workstation.
  • .NET Framework 4.0 or later.
  • Microsoft Excel installed.
  • At least one authoring tool, such as Adobe FrameMaker or Microsoft Word.
  • Access to the Acme Tray on your system.
  • A network folder that contains a small set of source data files you can use for this practice project.

docs.title: Step 1. Install TDU
docs.text:
1. In your Windows System Tray, right-click the Acme icon.

  2. Select Tech Doc Utility.

  3. When the installer prompt appears, click OK to approve the installation.

TDU installs itself the first time you launch it this way. On later launches, it checks for updates and installs the latest version if needed.

docs.title: Step 2. Start a new project
docs.text:
1. Launch Tech Doc Utility from the Acme Tray.

  2. On the startup page, click New.

  3. Enter a name for your practice project, for example TDU Demo Project.
  4. Confirm that the new project opens in its own tab.

docs.title: Step 3. Enter required metadata
docs.text:
1. Go to the Metadata tab.

  2. Fill in at least the required fields:

    • Master Record: Enter the ID of the appropriate master record in the Acme database. For this tutorial, use the test ID ABCD1234.

    • Sources: Browse to and select the main folder that contains your practice source data. This is the folder TDU will scan, index, and open when you search or correlate source data.

    • Documents: Choose or create a folder where TDU will create new documents.

    • Author: Add yourself as an author using the format firstname.lastname that matches your internal directory.

  3. Save the project.

docs.title: Step 4. Generate the source list
docs.text:
1. Go to the Sources tab.

  2. Click Create source list.

TDU scans the Sources folder and builds a source list for the project. When processing finishes, you should see your research files listed in the Sources tab.

Tip

The more files in the Sources folder, the more time and system resources this step will use. For this first project, keep the folder small.

docs.title: Step 5. Add documents to the document plan
docs.text:
You can either import a plan from a spreadsheet or add a few documents manually.

  • Import from spreadsheet

    1. In Excel, create a small spreadsheet with a few documents you want in this project. Include columns that match your internal template for document plans.
    2. Save the spreadsheet as .xlsx, .xls, or .csv.
    3. In TDU, go to the Document Plan tab.

    4. Use the import option to load your spreadsheet.

  • Add documents manually

    1. In the Document Plan tab, right-click in the document list.
    2. Choose Add Chapter, Add Subject, or Add Task.
    3. In the pop-up dialog, enter the requested information for each new document.

    4. Repeat until you have a small set of documents in your plan.

Success

You now have a basic TDU project that you can use to explore correlation, annotation, and reporting features.

  • The project opens correctly and shows your project name.
  • The Metadata tab contains your required fields.
  • The Sources tab lists your source data.
  • The Document Plan tab lists your documents.

docs.title: How-to: Verify TDU reporting inputs
docs.text:
Use this procedure to confirm that a TDU project is ready for reporting. You will check metadata, the source list, and the document plan for obvious issues before stakeholders start using reports.

Goal

Confirm that the core inputs for reporting are present and consistent.

docs.title: Before you start
docs.text:
Confirm that you have:

  • Completed metadata configuration.
  • Built the source list at least once.
  • Imported or created an initial document plan.

docs.title: Steps
docs.text:
1. In the Metadata tab, confirm that required fields are populated, especially:

    • Master Record ID
    • Central Data Path
    • Production Path

    • In the Sources tab, confirm that a source list exists.

    • Spot-check that the files listed match the cleaned source files for the agreed project scope.

    • In the Document Plan tab, spot-check several entries:

    • Each document has the correct type and status.

    • Author assignments use the correct firstname.lastname identifiers.

    • If you see problems, fix them now:

    • Update metadata values and save the project.

    • Refresh the source list if files or paths changed.
    • Correct document plan entries and save again.

Outcome

The project metadata, source list, and document plan are aligned and current, so TDU reports can represent the project accurately.
